Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Vertical GaN Nanostructures on Silicon Fins for Power Electronics and Future Integration with Silicon Technology

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Overview: The objective of this project is innovative research for developing III-nitride fin field-effect transistors on silicon substrate. The approach utilizes silicon support fins with (111)-oriented sidewalls for selective area growth of symmetric III-nitride heterostructures using metallorganic vapor phase epitaxy. Materials growth, nanofabrication, simulation and modeling, and electrical tests will be carried out to exploit the enormous flexibility in engineering the fin energy band structure, leading to unprecedented control of electronic properties.
Intellectual merit: This proposal presents transformative ideas, leading to novel and effective electronic device architectures for high-power transistors on a silicon platform. The proposed innovations will address fundamental and applied research related to materials growth, nano- and micro-scale design and development of wide band gap semiconductor transistors, and fabrication principles for fin architectures on structured silicon substrates. The III-nitride/Si fins will exhibit new band structure physics that will be exploited for innovative enhancement-mode devices.
Broader impacts: Efficient transistors are needed for high power radio-frequency modulation in wireless communications, DC power conversion, and imaging. Nanoscale biological and chemical sensors are needed for environmental monitoring, medical diagnostics, and homeland security. Normal-off state transistors for chip-scale miniature electronics are important for future ?green energy? applications. This proposal will enhance graduate and undergraduate education opportunities at Texas A&M and Texas Tech Universities and, strengthen diversity at each institution, lead to REU supplement requests, and initiate a program targeting junior and senior high students who are demographically underrepresented in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on innovative materials research for developing III-nitride fin field-effect transistors on silicon substrate. The approach utilizes silicon support nano fins for subsequent selective area growth of semiconducting III-nitride heterostructures. Preliminary work showed that gallium nitride (GaN) could be grown on the side walls of the silicon fins. A critical task in growth of GaN-based fins on silicon stripes is the quality of the silicon surface. Under this project, the team explored approaches for producing the silicon nano fins and developed wet etching procedures to produce smooth sidewalls and smooth interfin regions. Control over the fin width, down to 30 nm, and large height-to-width aspect ratio of 8:1 is readily achieved. Atomic force microscopy was used to study the surface properties, with specific attention to roughness. Growth of III-nitride semiconductors on silicon and other substrates relies on deposition of an AlN nucleation layer with full coverage but is very thin, approximately 10 nm. High quality AlN layers with nitrogen polarity are successfully grown using pre-deposition of a monocrystalline silicon nitride buffer layer. The formation of fin heterostructures in which multiple grain boundaries are present gives rise to additional dielectric interactions. Atomic layer deposition of aluminum oxide dielectric has been carried out on InGaN to determine the reaction mechanisms in preparation for gate stacks on the GaN fin devices. For effective electrical isolation, research was conducted on deposition of several promising candidates as isolation layers including aluminum oxide, hafnium oxide, and “native” gallium oxide. In each of these materials, the surface and optical properties were used to investigate the electronic structure related to the oxide formation. Results were backed by simulations of the energy band structure. The results here help pave the way to three-dimensional electronics based on GaN.
